name: Great Britain Alphabetically - Part A Quiz | Geography | 10 Questions

questions.text: Which seaside resort is home to the National Library of Wales, and the University College of Wales?
questions.explanation:
Aberystwyth.

	Aberystwyth is located in Ceredigion, on Cardigan Bay.

questions.text: Which Cumbria town is the site of a famous annual horse fair?
questions.explanation:
Appleby.

	Appleby was the county town of the former county of Westmorland, before it disappeared in 1974. The horse fair is held there each June.

questions.text: Which Scottish city is sometimes referred to as the 'Oil Capital of Europe'?
questions.explanation:
Aberdeen.

	Aberdeen has long been nicknamed the Granite City, but added the new moniker when oil was discovered in the North Sea in the 1970s.

questions.text: Which town is the county town of Buckinghamshire, and lends its name to a breed of duck?
questions.explanation:
Aylesbury.

	Aylesbury was declared the county town of Buckinghamshire by King Henry VIII in 1529.

questions.text: Which Ayrshire village was the birthplace of the Scottish poet Robert Burns?
questions.explanation:
Alloway.

	Burns was born in Alloway in 1759.

questions.text: Which Sussex town is home to a castle which is the ancestral home of the Duke of Norfolk?
questions.explanation:
Arundel.

	The castle has existed since the 11th century; Arundel is also home to a cathedral, dedicated in 1873.

questions.text: Which town in Suffolk is the site of an annual classical music festival?
questions.explanation:
Aldeburgh.

	The Aldeburgh Festival was founded in 1948 by Benjamin Britten. Aldeburgh also found fame in 1908 as the first British town to elect a female Mayor - Elizabeth Garrett Anderson.

questions.text: Which small Berkshire town is famous for its racecourse, the site of an annual Royal horse racing meeting?
questions.explanation:
Ascot.

	The Royal Ascot race meeting takes place every June, and is a highlight of the social as well as the sporting calendar; the royal family attend each day of the meeting.

questions.text: Which small town in Devon is synonymous with the carpets manufactured there?
questions.explanation:
Axminster.

	Carpets have been made in Axminster since 1755.

questions.text: Which Scottish fishing port is famous for its 'smokies' - haddock flavoured and smoked from an oak fire?
questions.explanation:
Arbroath.

	Arbroath is also famous for the Declaration of Arbroath, a statement of Scottish independence signed in the 14th century.
